home.hero.title: Mentivio – A Gentle Space for Your Mind
home.hero.subtitle: Take a compassionate step toward understanding your mental health with our safe, evidence-based tools and resources.
home.crisis.alert_description: If you are feeling unsafe or thinking about self-harm, please reach out for help right now. You do not have to face this alone.
home.features.title: Your Wellness Toolkit
home.features.subtitle: Simple, proven tools to help you understand and nurture your mind
home.features.assessment.title: Self-Check
home.features.assessment.desc: A private, clinically-backed assessment to help you spot patterns in your mental health.
home.features.insights.title: Understanding Conditions
home.features.insights.desc: Learn about mental health conditions through clear explanations and interactive visuals.
home.features.resources.title: Knowledge Library
home.features.resources.desc: Access trusted guides, coping strategies, and support for various mental health topics.
home.tips.title: Small Habits, Big Impact
home.tips.subtitle: Simple daily steps to support your wellbeing
home.tips.mindful.title: Just Breathe
home.tips.mindful.desc: Take 5 minutes to focus on your breath. Inhale for 4 counts, exhale for 6.
home.tips.detox.title: Unplug & Reset
home.tips.detox.desc: Schedule 30 minutes screen-free time daily to declutter your mind.
home.tips.gratitude.title: Practice Gratitude
home.tips.gratitude.desc: Write down three things you are thankful for today to shift your perspective.
home.tips.movement.title: Move Your Body
home.tips.movement.desc: Take a short walk or stretch every hour to refresh both mind and body.
home.professional.title: Expert Guidance Matters
home.professional.desc: Our tools are for education and self-awareness. Please always consult a healthcare professional for medical diagnosis and advice.
home.resources.title: Trusted Support Networks
home.resources.subtitle: National organizations offering professional support
home.resources.988.title: 988 Lifeline
home.resources.988.desc: Free, confidential support available 24/7 for anyone in distress.
home.resources.nami.title: NAMI Helpline
home.resources.nami.desc: Free peer support and resources from the National Alliance on Mental Illness.
home.resources.textline.title: Crisis Text Line
home.resources.textline.desc: Free 24/7 support via text with trained crisis counselors.
home.resources.mentalgov.title: MentalHealth.gov
home.resources.mentalgov.desc: Official U.S. government resource for finding mental health treatment.

resources.hero-subtitle: Reliable information on conditions, treatments, and how to cope
resources.resource1-desc: Understand the symptoms, causes, and effective treatments for depression. Covers major depressive disorder and persistent depression.
resources.resource2-desc: A complete overview of anxiety disorders, including generalized anxiety, panic attacks, and social anxiety.
resources.resource3-desc: Explore different approaches like CBT, DBT, and psychodynamic therapy to find what fits you best.
resources.resource4-desc: Practical techniques for grounding, meditation, and staying present to manage stress.
resources.resource5-desc: Insights into Bipolar I, II, and Cyclothymia. Learn about mood stabilization and managing episodes.
resources.resource6-desc: Build a personalized routine with tips for physical, emotional, and mental wellbeing.
resources.resource7-desc: Understanding trauma responses, PTSD symptoms, and paths to recovery.
resources.resource8-desc: What you need to know about common psychiatric medications, side effects, and talking to your doctor.
resources.faq1-question: How do I know if I need help?
resources.faq1-answer: If symptoms are causing you distress, affecting your daily life/work, or if you have thoughts of self-harm, please seek professional help immediately.
resources.faq2-answer: Psychiatrists are medical doctors who can prescribe medication. Psychologists focus on talk therapy and evaluations. Both play key roles in care.
resources.faq3-answer: It varies. Some people feel better after short-term therapy (8-12 sessions), while others benefit from longer-term support.
resources.faq4-answer: Yes, research shows online therapy can be just as effective as in-person sessions for many conditions.
resources.newsletter-subtitle: Get mental health tips and new resources delivered to your inbox
resources.support2-desc: Government portal for finding treatment services.
resources.support3-desc: Find licensed professionals in your local area.

anxiety-resource.hero-subtitle: A guide to the different types of anxiety and how to manage them
anxiety-resource.section1-p1: Feeling anxious occasionally is normal—everyone worries about health, money, or family sometimes. But anxiety disorders are different.
anxiety-resource.section1-p2: For those with an anxiety disorder, the worry doesn't fade; it can worsen over time and interfere with work, school, and relationships.
anxiety-resource.stat-text: About 1/3 of adults in the U.S. will experience an anxiety disorder at some point.
anxiety-resource.type1-desc: Excessive, persistent worry about everyday things without a specific cause.
anxiety-resource.type2-desc: Sudden, intense panic attacks and the constant fear of having another one.
anxiety-resource.type3-desc: Intense fear of social situations, judgment, or embarrassment.
anxiety-resource.type4-desc: Irrational fear of specific things like heights, flying, or spiders.
anxiety-resource.type5-desc: Fear of places or situations where escape might be difficult.
anxiety-resource.type6-desc: Excessive fear of being apart from loved ones.
anxiety-resource.section3-p1: Anxiety affects both mind and body:
anxiety-resource.section4-p1: Try these techniques to calm your system:
anxiety-resource.strategy1-desc: Try the 4-7-8 technique: Inhale for 4, hold for 7, exhale for 8.
anxiety-resource.strategy2-desc: Identify 5 things you see, 4 you feel, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste.
anxiety-resource.strategy3-desc: Tense and then relax muscle groups to release physical stress.
anxiety-resource.strategy4-desc: Challenge anxious thoughts by asking: 'Is this actually true?'
anxiety-resource.strategy5-desc: Observe your thoughts without judgment. Stay in the now.
anxiety-resource.strategy6-desc: Limit caffeine, exercise regularly, and prioritize sleep.
anxiety-resource.section5-p1: Anxiety is highly treatable. Options include:
anxiety-resource.treatment1: CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): The gold standard for changing anxious thought patterns.
anxiety-resource.treatment2: Exposure Therapy: Safely facing fears to reduce their power.
anxiety-resource.treatment3: ACT (Acceptance & Commitment Therapy): Learning to live with anxiety while focusing on values.
anxiety-resource.treatment4: Medication: Anti-anxiety meds or antidepressants can help manage symptoms.
anxiety-resource.treatment5: Mindfulness Therapy: Using awareness to reduce stress.
anxiety-resource.section5-p2: A combination of therapy and medication often works best.
anxiety-resource.section6-p1: If anxiety stops you from living your life, reach out.
anxiety-resource.section6-p2: Start with your primary doctor to rule out physical issues.
anxiety-resource.section6-p3: Then, connect with a mental health specialist for tailored support.
anxiety-resource.source-text: Source: National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH). Learn more at

bipolar-resource.hero-subtitle: Understanding mood swings, stabilization, and managing the condition
bipolar-resource.section1-p1: Bipolar disorder causes extreme mood swings that include emotional highs (mania) and lows (depression). These aren't just normal mood changes—they can be severe and disruptive.
bipolar-resource.stat-text: It affects about 5.7 million American adults.
bipolar-resource.section1-p2: These shifts can affect sleep, energy, judgment, and the ability to think clearly.
bipolar-resource.type1-desc: Involves manic episodes lasting at least 7 days, or severe mania requiring hospital care. Depressive episodes usually occur as well.
bipolar-resource.type1-feature: Key: At least one full manic episode.
bipolar-resource.type2-desc: A pattern of depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes (less severe highs), but no full-blown mania.
bipolar-resource.type3-desc: Periods of hypomanic symptoms and depressive symptoms lasting for at least 2 years.
bipolar-resource.manic-symptom2: Little need for sleep but feeling energetic
bipolar-resource.manic-note: Note: Hypomania is a milder version that doesn't severely disrupt daily function.
bipolar-resource.feature1-desc: Symptoms of mania and depression happening at the same time.
bipolar-resource.feature2-desc: Having four or more episodes in a year.
bipolar-resource.feature3-desc: Severe episodes may include hallucinations or delusions.
bipolar-resource.section4-p1: Bipolar is a lifelong condition, but it can be managed well:
bipolar-resource.treatment-success: With the right plan, you can lead a stable, fulfilling life.
bipolar-resource.section5-p1: Catching it early makes a difference:
bipolar-resource.prevention2-item1: Make a plan with your doctor
bipolar-resource.source-text: Source: NIMH and Cleveland Clinic. Learn more at

depression-resource.hero-subtitle: A guide to recognizing signs, understanding causes, and finding hope
depression-resource.section1-p1: We all feel low sometimes, but usually, it passes. Depression is different—it's a serious medical condition that impacts how you feel, think, and act every day.
depression-resource.section1-p2: It isn't just 'sadness'. It can feel like a heavy weight, making work, school, or socializing feel impossible. The important thing to know is: it is treatable.
depression-resource.section1-p3: It can happen to anyone. It's often a mix of genetics, biology, environment, and psychology.
depression-resource.section2-p1: Depression looks different for everyone, but common signs include:
depression-resource.symptom3: Eating too much or loss of appetite
depression-resource.section2-p2: If these feelings last more than two weeks, please see a doctor.
depression-resource.type1-desc: Severe symptoms interfering with life, lasting 2+ weeks.
depression-resource.type2-desc: Milder but long-lasting (2 years or more).
depression-resource.type3-desc: Depression related to seasons, usually winter.
depression-resource.type5-desc: Severe depression with hallucinations or delusions.
depression-resource.section4-p1: Most people get better with help:
depression-resource.treatment2-note: Meds typically take 4-8 weeks to work fully.
depression-resource.section4-p2: Combining therapy and medication is often most effective. You may need to try a few options to find what works for you.
depression-resource.section5-p1: Asking for help is brave, not weak.
depression-resource.section5-p2: Start with a general practitioner to rule out other health issues.
depression-resource.section5-p3: See a therapist or psychiatrist for specialized care.
depression-resource.section5-p4: Build a circle of friends or family who can support you.
depression-resource.source-text: Source: National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH). Learn more at

mindfulness-resource.hero-subtitle: Practical ways to reduce stress and find balance
mindfulness-resource.section1-p1: Mindfulness is simply paying attention to the present moment intentionally and without judgment. It's about noticing what's happening right now, inside and out.
mindfulness-resource.section1-tip-text: The goal isn't to clear your mind. It's to notice when your mind wanders and gently bring it back.
mindfulness-resource.section1-p2: You can practice it sitting in meditation, or while walking, eating, or doing dishes.
mindfulness-resource.research-highlight-text: Mindfulness helps us 'de-center' from negative thoughts, reducing the risk of spiraling into anxiety or depression.
mindfulness-resource.step1-desc: Sit or lie down where you can be comfortable.
mindfulness-resource.step3-desc: Feel the air moving in and out. Don't force it, just watch it.
mindfulness-resource.step4-desc: When thoughts pop up (they will!), smile, acknowledge them, and go back to the breath.
mindfulness-resource.step5-desc: Don't judge yourself. The 'practice' is the act of coming back.
mindfulness-resource.breathing-p2: Repeat 4 times to reset your nervous system.
mindfulness-resource.section4-p1: Pick one that resonates with you:
mindfulness-resource.ex1-desc: Mentally scan your body from toe to head, noticing tension and releasing it.
mindfulness-resource.ex2-desc: Walk slowly. Feel your feet hit the ground. Notice the air on your skin.
mindfulness-resource.ex3-desc: Send good wishes to yourself and others: 'May I be happy, may I be safe.'
mindfulness-resource.ex4-desc: Eat slowly. Notice texture, taste, and smell. Put the fork down between bites.
mindfulness-resource.ex5-desc: Name: 5 things you see, 4 feel, 3 hear, 2 smell, 1 taste.
mindfulness-resource.ex6-desc: Recognize, Allow, Investigate, Nurture (for difficult emotions).
mindfulness-resource.tip2: Take a 60-second breath break at work
mindfulness-resource.tip4: Brush your teeth mindfully (feel the bristles, taste the paste)
mindfulness-resource.tip5: Check in with your body tension
mindfulness-resource.tip6: Do one thing at a time (single-tasking)
mindfulness-resource.learning-tip-text: If apps don't work for you, look for a local class or teacher.
mindfulness-resource.source-info-text: Source: National Institutes of Health (NIH). Learn more at

exercises.body-scan: Body Scan: Lie down. Focus on each body part from toes to head. Just notice sensations.
exercises.walking: Walking: Walk slowly. Feel your feet connect with the earth. Notice your surroundings.
exercises.loving-kindness: Loving-Kindness: Repeat 'May I be happy, may I be healthy' for yourself, then others.
exercises.eating: Mindful Eating: Look at your food. Smell it. Taste it slowly. Savor it.
exercises.senses: 5 Senses: Name 5 things you see, 4 you feel, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste.
exercises.rain: RAIN: Recognize the feeling, Allow it, Investigate with kindness, Nurture yourself.

medication-resource.hero-subtitle: A clear guide to how they work and what to expect
medication-resource.section1-p1: Medications work by balancing chemicals in the brain. They are tools that work best when paired with therapy and self-care.
medication-resource.section1-important: Note: Everyone is different. You might need to try a few options to find the right fit. Patience is key.
medication-resource.section1-p2: This guide helps you talk to your doctor. Always follow medical advice for treatment.
medication-resource.section2-p1: Knowing the timeline helps reduce anxiety:
medication-resource.section2-remember: Remember: Most meds take 4-8 weeks to work fully. Don't give up too soon.
medication-resource.class1-how: Balance serotonin/dopamine to improve mood and sleep.
medication-resource.class1-type1: SSRIs (Prozac, Zoloft): Most common, fewer side effects.
medication-resource.guide1-item2: Side effects: Usually fade in 1-2 weeks.
medication-resource.guide2-item1: Take it at the same time daily.
medication-resource.guide3-item1: Tell them everything you take (vitamins too).
medication-resource.safety1-item1: Antidepressants: Nausea, sleep issues, weight change.
medication-resource.safety1-item2: Mood Stabilizers: Thirst, tremors, weight gain.
medication-resource.safety2-item2: Serotonin Syndrome: Fever, confusion, racing heart (ER now).
medication-resource.safety3-item2: Supplements like St. John's Wort interact.
medication-resource.question1: What exactly will this help with?
medication-resource.question5: How long do I need to take this?
medication-resource.question6: What if I miss a dose?
medication-resource.question8: How do we know it's working?
medication-resource.question10: How do I stop taking it safely?
medication-resource.question11: Does it mix with my other meds?
medication-resource.question14: What if I get side effects?
medication-resource.emergency1-desc: Thoughts of hurting self or others.
medication-resource.disclaimer-text: This is educational info, not medical advice. Always talk to your doctor before changing meds. Don't stop meds without supervision.
medication-resource.source-text: Source: NIMH and NAMI. Learn more at

ptsd-resource.hero-subtitle: Understanding trauma and the path to recovery
ptsd-resource.section1-p1: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) can happen after living through something terrifying. It's normal to feel shaken after trauma, but PTSD is when that fear sticks around and disrupts your life.
ptsd-resource.stat-text: About 6% of people experience PTSD. Women are more likely to have it.
ptsd-resource.section1-p2: Symptoms usually start within 3 months but can happen later. It's diagnosed when symptoms last over a month and affect daily living.
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item1: Flashbacks: Feeling like you're back there.
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item2: Nightmares: Bad dreams about the event.
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item3: Intrusive thoughts: Memories popping up uninvited.
ptsd-resource.cluster1-item4: Physical reaction: Heart racing when reminded.
ptsd-resource.section3-p1: Not everyone gets PTSD. Factors include:
ptsd-resource.resilience-item2: Accepting your actions during the event.
ptsd-resource.treatment1-item1: CPT (Cognitive Processing Therapy): Changing beliefs about the trauma.
ptsd-resource.treatment1-item2: PE (Prolonged Exposure): Safely facing the memories.
ptsd-resource.treatment1-item3: EMDR: Using eye movements to process memories.
ptsd-resource.treatment2-note: Note: Benzos are generally avoided for PTSD.
ptsd-resource.technique1-item1-desc: Name 5 things seen, 4 felt, 3 heard, 2 smelled, 1 tasted.
ptsd-resource.technique1-item2-desc: Hold ice or splash cold water on face to reset.
ptsd-resource.technique1-item4-desc: Feel feet on floor, back on chair.
ptsd-resource.technique2-item1-desc: Know your triggers and who to call.
ptsd-resource.source-text: Source: NIMH and National Center for PTSD. Learn more at

selfcare-resource.hero-subtitle: Nurturing yourself to stay balanced and healthy
selfcare-resource.section1-p1: Self-care means deliberately doing things that take care of your mental, emotional, and physical health. It's about refueling yourself.
selfcare-resource.stat-text: 64% of people practice it, and most want to do more.
selfcare-resource.section1-p2: It isn't selfish. It's like putting on your oxygen mask first so you can help others. Small acts count.
selfcare-resource.section1-p3: It shouldn't be a chore. It should make you feel better.
selfcare-resource.step3-desc: Block out 15 mins. Protect that time.
selfcare-resource.step4-desc: If it doesn't work, try something else.
selfcare-resource.no-list-text: The 'NO' List: What will you stop doing? (e.g., Checking email at night).
selfcare-resource.barrier1-solution: Start with 1 minute. It saves time by preventing burnout.
selfcare-resource.barrier2-solution: You can't pour from an empty cup.
selfcare-resource.barrier4-solution: Walking, breathing, and sleeping are free.
selfcare-resource.barrier5-solution: It's an investment in being a better you.
selfcare-resource.barrier6-solution: Pick low-energy things: Music, bath, nap.
selfcare-resource.emergency-intro: Self-care isn't medical care. See a pro if symptoms last 2+ weeks:
selfcare-resource.source-text: Source: NIMH and Mental Health First Aid. Learn more at

therapy-resource.hero-subtitle: Find the approach that fits you
therapy-resource.section1-p1: Psychotherapy (talk therapy) creates a safe space to explore feelings and learn coping skills with a professional.
therapy-resource.section1-how-desc: You talk about your life, and the therapist helps you find patterns and solutions.
therapy-resource.effectiveness-note: It works. Combining it with medication is often best.
therapy-resource.section2-p1: CBT links Thoughts, Feelings, and Behaviors. It fixes negative thinking.
therapy-resource.section3-p1: Mixes CBT with Mindfulness. Focuses on accepting feelings while changing behaviors.
therapy-resource.section4-p1: Explores how the past and unconscious mind affect you now.
therapy-resource.psychodynamic-meta1: Best for: Deep patterns, Personality issues
therapy-resource.emdr-desc: Uses eye movements to process trauma.
therapy-resource.tip1-desc: Want quick relief or deep understanding?
therapy-resource.tip2-desc: Choose what's proven for your issue.
therapy-resource.tip3-desc: You must feel comfortable with the therapist.
therapy-resource.choosing-note: Note: You can switch therapists if it's not working.

about.hero-subtitle: Approaching mental health with empathy and education
about.mission-statement: "We empower you with knowledge and tools to understand your mind and take care of yourself."
about.story-subtitle: Our journey to make help accessible
about.timeline-2024-content: After facing my own struggles with depression, I saw how many others suffer in silence. I wanted to create a place where no one feels lost.
about.timeline-2025-content: I teamed up with experts to build tools that bridge the gap between medical care and daily life. The goal: Help for everyone, everywhere.
about.subtimeline-august25-content: Brainstorming and gathering data to build a solid base.
about.subtimeline-october25-content: Creating smart models to offer accurate assessments.
about.subtimeline-december25-content: Adding languages to reach people worldwide.
about.timeline-now-content: Mentivio is a promise that you aren't alone. It's built with heart for anyone seeking support.
about.value-privacy-content: Your journey is private. We keep your data safe.
about.value-empowerment-content: Giving you the tools to make good choices.
about.value-compassion-content: We lead with empathy. We meet you where you are.
about.team-founder-bio: Started Mentivio from personal experience. Believes everyone deserves support.
about.team-advisors-bio: Licensed pros ensuring accuracy and care.
about.team-community-bio: Your stories inspire us every day.

crisis.header-subtitle: Help is available. Your safety comes first.
crisis.emergency-subtitle: If you are in danger or hurting, reach out now.
crisis.emergency-services-desc: Call 911 or go to the ER.
crisis.crisis-info-subtitle: Know the signs and act fast.
crisis.recognize-content: Severe mood swings, talk of death, hopelessness.
crisis.calm-content: Breathe. Your calm helps them feel safe.
crisis.cta-subtitle: Asking for help is brave. We are here.

analogy.analogy_hero_description0: Visualize the difference between Bipolar I, II, Depression, and Normal moods.
analogy.analogy_disclaimer_text0: This is for education, not diagnosis. Everyone is different.

manic: I feel unstoppable! Sleep is a waste of time!
My ideas are flashing like lightning!
Why is everyone so slow? I need to do it ALL now!
I'm starting 3 companies today! Let's go!
I'm invincible! Let's take a risk!
depressive: Why did I do that? I'm a failure.
My mind is blank. Why bother?
Everyone is better off without me.

conversations0: I'm super productive lately! Hope it lasts...
I feel great, but a bit buzzed...
Did so much in just a few hours!
I can't stop talking, so much to share!
High energy now, but I fear the crash.
Today was okay. Ups and downs, but manageable.
That was tough, but I'll handle it.

analogy.analogy_summary_bipolar1_description0: Extreme Ride - Includes full manic episodes that can be dangerous.
analogy.analogy_summary_bipolar2_description0: Mild Up, Deep Down - Hypomania (manageable highs) mixed with deep depression.
analogy.analogy_summary_normal_description0: The Waves - Natural emotions that don't stop your life.
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_high_mood_content0:
Mania
• Explodes with energy
• Risky/Dangerous
• Hospital likely
• Psychosis possible
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_high_mood_content0:
Hypomania
• Milder high
• Productive
• No psychosis
• No hospital needed
analogy.analogy_normal_high_mood_content0:
Normal Joy
• Happy moments
• Fits situation
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_low_mood_content0:
Severe Depression
• Crushing
• Debilitating
• Follows mania
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_low_mood_content0:
Severe Depression
• More frequent
• Longer lasting
• Main problem
analogy.analogy_depression_low_mood_content0:
Severe Depression
• Only mood state
• No ups
• Persistent
analogy.analogy_normal_low_mood_content0:
Sadness
• Short-term
• Valid reason
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_energy_content0:
Extreme High + Low
• Mania: Too much
• Depression: None
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_energy_content0:
High + Low
• Hypo: Energetic
• Dep: Tired
analogy.analogy_depression_energy_content0:
Always Low
• Fatigue
• Slow
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_sleep_content0:
No sleep (Mania)
• Awake but wired
• Oversleep (Depression)
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_sleep_content0:
Less sleep (Hypo)
• Don't need as much
• Oversleep (Depression)
analogy.analogy_depression_sleep_content0:
Sleep Issues
• Insomnia or Oversleeping
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_impact_content0:
Disruptive
• Stops life/work
• Damages bonds
analogy.analogy_bipolar2_impact_content0:
Significant
• Hard to work
• Strains bonds
analogy.analogy_depression_impact_content0:
Severe
• Poor performance
• Isolation
analogy.analogy_bipolar1_diagnosis_content0:
MANIA defines it
Key: Must have full Mania

app.title: Mentivio - Mental Health Check
app.description: Safe, private, and clinical mental health assessment.

prediction.hero-description: Take a safe, clinical assessment to better understand your mind and get personalized insights.
prediction.welcome-description: This holistic check-in looks at your mood, sleep, anxiety, and behavior patterns. Your answers will help paint a picture of your current mental wellbeing.
prediction.important-note-text: This is for information only, not a medical diagnosis. Your data is encrypted and safe.
prediction.review-description: Double-check everything. Click an answer to edit if needed.
prediction.review-note-text: Remember your Name and Patient ID so you can see your history later.
prediction.normal-description: Your results show typical mental health patterns with no significant concerns.
prediction.disclaimer-text: This is not a substitute for a doctor's advice. Please see a professional if you are unwell.

questions.Q1: Do you experience sudden mood swings?
questions.Q2: How often do you feel sad or down?
questions.Q3: Do you ever feel unusually high energy or euphoric?
questions.Q4: Do you struggle with sleep (falling/staying asleep)?
questions.Q5: Do you feel tired or drained often?
questions.Q6: Have you had thoughts of hurting yourself?
questions.Q7: Do you get aggressive or hostile in conflicts?
questions.Q8: Have you felt emotionally overwhelmed recently?
questions.Q9: Do you worry or overthink too much?
questions.Q12: Do you try to explain your side during conflicts?
questions.Q13: Do you tend to avoid problems?
questions.Q14: Can you admit when you're wrong?
questions.Q16: What is your outlook on life?
questions.Q17: How is your interest in sex?

diagnosisDescriptions.Normal: Your responses suggest a stable mental health profile.
diagnosisDescriptions.Bipolar Type-1: Responses suggest potential Bipolar I patterns (manic episodes).
diagnosisDescriptions.Bipolar Type-2: Responses suggest Bipolar II patterns (depression + hypomania).
diagnosisDescriptions.Depression: Responses align with depression patterns (sadness, loss of interest).
diagnosisDescriptions.default_description: Assessment complete. Please consult a doctor for a full diagnosis.

errors.noNumberConfirm: No Patient ID. Continue without saving?
errors.deleteConfirm: Delete this? It cannot be undone.
errors.noDataForDownload: No data yet. Complete an assessment first.

warnings.suicidal_thoughts: Alert: Suicidal thoughts detected - Seek help immediately

pdf_report.title: MENTAL HEALTH REPORT
pdf_report.question: Question
pdf_report.disclaimer_text:
This report is for information only. It does not replace a medical diagnosis. Please see a doctor for advice.

If you are in danger, call emergency services immediately.
